concern: How do you make friends in college? I graduated hs recently and I didnâ€™t have friends in hs so Iâ€™m not the best at socializing. I start next month and I really want to make friends and have a good time but I donâ€™t know how people are here ðŸ˜­ Iâ€™m just really nervous about even walking into class and finding a seat..

dialogue_total.statement: Hello, and welcome! I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. Feel free to share whatever's on your mindâ€”I'm all ears and ready to support you.
Hey, thanks for being here. Iâ€™m just really nervous about starting college next month and figuring out how to make friends since I didnâ€™t have any in high school.
It's totally normal to feel nervous about starting college, especially when it comes to making friends. Can you tell me more about what you're worried about?

Yeah, I guess Iâ€™m just worried about not knowing how to even start a conversation or fit in with people. It feels like everyone else already knows what theyâ€™re doing, and Iâ€™m just gonna be super awkward or out of place.

You seem to feel a bit overwhelmed about starting college and making friends, especially with the fear of feeling awkward or out of place. That's completely understandable, and I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Thanks, I really appreciate that. I just keep thinking Iâ€™ll mess up somehow, like say the wrong thing or not know how to act around new people.

It sounds like youâ€™re really worried about making a mistake and not knowing how to interact with new people, which is making you feel anxious and unsure about starting college. Can you tell me more about what you think might happen if you do say the wrong thing or donâ€™t know how to act?

Honestly, Iâ€™m scared that if I say something dumb or act weird, people will just judge me or not want to talk to me at all. I feel like Iâ€™ll end up alone again, like I was in high school, and that thought just kinda freaks me out.

It sounds like you're really worried about making a mistake and not knowing how to interact with new people, which is making you feel anxious and unsure about starting college. Can you tell me more about what you think might happen if you do say the wrong thing or don't know how to act?

Yeah, I just keep imagining that if I mess up, people will think Iâ€™m weird or just not worth getting to know. Itâ€™s like Iâ€™ll be stuck on my own again, and I really donâ€™t want to go through that feeling of being left out all over.

I hear how much you want to connect with others and avoid feeling left out, and that fear of being judged is really holding you back. What if we explored ways you could start small, like just introducing yourself to one person in your class or joining a club that interests you, to see how things go and maybe build some confidence before diving in fully?

That sounds like a good idea, but Iâ€™m still kinda nervous about even starting with just one person or a club. I mean, what if I donâ€™t know what to say or they donâ€™t seem interested in talking to me?

I understand that starting with even just one person or a club can still feel daunting, but it might help to focus on small steps that feel manageable. What if you thought of a few simple icebreaker questions you could ask others, like how they like the class or their favorite hobby? That way, you could start conversations without feeling like you need to be the one talking the whole time.

Yeah, I like the idea of having some go-to questions to break the ice, but I still worry Iâ€™ll freeze up or sound super awkward when I ask them. I guess I just donâ€™t trust myself to not mess it up, you know?

It's completely understandable that you're worried about feeling awkward, but remember that everyone gets nervous sometimes. Even if you do freeze up or stumble over your words, you could reframe that moment as a chance to show others that you're human and relatable. And hey, what if you practiced asking those icebreaker questions in front of a mirror or with a trusted friend? That might help you feel more comfortable and confident when the time comes.

Yeah, practicing in front of a mirror or with someone I trust could help, I think, just to get the hang of it without the pressure. Iâ€™m just kinda scared that even with practice, Iâ€™ll still come off as weird or out of place when I actually try it in real life, you know?

That fear of not fitting in is totally valid, but what if you reminded yourself that being a little different isn't a bad thing? People are often drawn to others who are genuine and authentic, even if they don't always fit the mold. Plus, you might be surprised by how many others feel just as nervous as you do in social situations.

Yeah, I get that being genuine matters, but I still canâ€™t shake the feeling that people might just see me as awkward instead of authentic. Itâ€™s like, I want to connect, but Iâ€™m so worried Iâ€™ll mess up that first impression, you know?

It's natural to want to make a good impression, but what if you shifted your focus from trying to be perfect to just being present and curious about others? That way, even if you stumble a bit, your genuine interest in connecting could shine through and help others see beyond any initial awkwardness.

Yeah, I like the idea of focusing on being curious about others instead of stressing over being perfect. Itâ€™s just hard to imagine that working when Iâ€™m already overthinking every little thing I say, you know?

I hear you, and it's understandable that old habits can be hard to break. Maybe you could try setting a small intention for yourself before entering a social situation, like asking one person a question about their interests, and then let go of the rest. Remember, the goal isn't to be perfect, but to be present and genuinely curious. And hey, if you do overthink things, you could even acknowledge it playfully with something like, ""Oops, I'm doing it again!"" to help lighten the moment.

Yeah, setting a small goal like asking one question sounds doable, and I think it might take some of the pressure off. Iâ€™m just still kinda worried that even with that, Iâ€™ll freeze up or say something dumb, you know?

Let's summarize your goals and action steps for our next session. We discussed the importance of focusing on being present and genuinely curious when engaging in social interactions, rather than striving for perfection. To help you achieve this, we agreed on setting a small intention before entering social situations, such as asking one person a question about their interests. We also discussed acknowledging overthinking moments playfully to help lighten the situation.
For your next steps, practice setting small intentions for social interactions and remember that the goal is to be present and genuinely curious. Try to reframe your thinking by reminding yourself that being different isn't a bad thing and that others may feel just as nervous as you do. Lastly, don't forget to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that it's okay to make mistakes.
Remember, it's all about taking small steps towards your goals, and I'm here to support you along the way. Let's continue to work on these strategies in our next session.

Thanks for summarizing everything, I really appreciate the reminder to take small steps and be kind to myself. Iâ€™m still a bit nervous about putting this into practice, but Iâ€™ll give it a shot and see how it feels.
